Aquatic ecosystem contaminated with toxic pollutants and heavy metals due to the rapid growth of industrialization has become a top-priority global concern exhibiting highly adverse effects on human health and the environment.Many treatment techniques have been envisioned for the removal of these toxic contaminants from the aqueous environment. Among these techniques, magnetic separation has attracted burgeoning research attention owing to its simplicity, eco-friendly nature, large surface area, electron mobility, and excellent performance for removingwater contaminants. In particular, interfacial active nanoparticles and nanocomposites with unique structures and magnetic properties are considered as ideal provides candidates in material science for nextgeneration water treatment. This review gives an insight into current research activities associated with the synthesis strategies and applications of interfacially active and magnetically responsive nanomaterials and nanocomposites for sustainable purification processes. In the first half, various synthesis routes for magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles development and the corresponding formation mechanism are summarized. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Extensive research work is in progress to design, synthesis, and preparation of magnetic composite materials (Walther and Müller, 2013). The field of material science offers a variety of micro and nanospheres and broadens their application perspective. Magnetic composite materials have been under profound consideration because of their potential applications in the environment (Zhang et al., 2012), sensor (Sun et al., 2012), agriculture (Pan et al., 2014), enzyme immobilization (Bilal et al., 2018a), and biomedicine (Nieciecka et al., 2013; Wei et al., 2014) (Fig. 1). These applications of multifunctional materials are owing to their exceptional properties such as the surface, vessel, and targeting effect, biocompatibility and the property of reuse and recycling after applying an external magnetic field (Adeel et al., 2018;

Significant research efforts have been made in the design and development of amphiphilic magnetic composite materials with different surface morphologies like core-shell, raspberry and Janus type with different particle size, shell thickness, magnetic content, and biocompatibility.
Magnetic composite nano and microspheres generally made up of magnetic nanoparticles impregnated in the magnetic or nonmagnetic matrix (Huang et al., 2002). However, nanoscale magnetic material dispersed in composites has a possibility of agglomeration for the possible decrease of energy due to the high specific surface to volume ratio of the nanoparticles. To circumvent this agglomeration/aggregation of magnetic nanoparticles, many approaches have been envisioned to protect and stabilize the neat magnetic particles by coating or to graft with some organic compounds, i.e., polymers, surfactants, or coating with
nano-materials and their potential applications with special reference to environment.
carbon or silica (Kango et al., 2013). Principally, there are four broad types ofmagnetic nanocomposites, i.e., self-assembled nanocomposites, core-shell nanocomposites, organic-inorganic nanocomposites, and silica-based nanocomposites (Fig. 2). Among these, the most important one is organic-inorganic magnetic composite nano and microspheres because of the organic and inorganic component and their unique surface properties. Hybrid magnetic organic-inorganic nanoparticles with catalytic properties can be prepared by emulsion, mini-emulsion followed by a solvothermal process, precipitation, plasma polymerization in situ, co-precipitation, microwave reflux, ceramic–glass processing, and melt blending techniques (Wei et al., 2011; Du et al., 2013; Reguyal et al., 2017; Taghizadeh et al., 2019).
Magnetic composite materials at liquid/liquid interfaces have many applications such as extraction of crude oil, mineral flotation, and food formulation. The theoretical and experimental findings revealed that the adsorption of amphiphilic magnetic composite material at fluid/ fluid interfaces and the stability of emulsions from the nanoparticles interfacial adsorption (Du et al., 2013). In this context, stimuli-responsive polymers are a new and promising set of materials. Inorganic materials are considered novel candidates to develop composites with tunable optical and electronic properties (Bhushan and Jung, 2011). Notably, magnetic nanoparticles includingmagnetite (Fe3O4) are potent carriers and biomarkers for a range of industrial applications because of their goodmagnetic responses and easy recovery and separation from amultiphase system by applying an external magnetic field. The development and assessment of novel nanosized inorganic composites in hybridization with stimuli-responsive materials have been proved useful to the water/oil interface (Liu et al., 2013). This interface is particularly attractive because nanoparticles trapped at water/oil interface can be chemically modified in either of the two bulk phases (Yao et al., 2011). Furthermore, stimuli-responsive polymers andmonolayers capped inorganic nanomaterials have been exploited to reversible control of the stability of the emulsion in immiscible water/oil systems by pH and temperature modulation (Zhang and Seeger, 2011). Based on this approach, many techniques are in practice and established to construct magnetic interfacial nanomaterials with superior amphiphilic properties for wide-ranging applications of (Xue et al., 2014). Among these applications, the self-cleaning textile (Kim et al., 2012; Wilson et al., 2013), separation of crude oil and water emulsion (Huang et al., 2007), antifogging glass (Hermelin et al., 2008) and active corrosion control (Vrijenhoek et al., 2001;Meng et al., 2008). Apart from these applications, some innovative nanomaterials with distinct interfacial and
wettability have also shown applications in technological research and development. For instance, these nanomaterials with excellent friction control have led to smart microfluidics (Li and Elimelech, 2004). Interfacially active andmagnetically responsivematerials play important role in numerous environmental practices, like membrane separations (Yang et al., 2006), adsorption (Herzberg and Elimelech, 2007), biological fouling (Wang et al., 2012), corrosion (Drelich and Chibowski, 2010), interfacial phase transition (Ma and Hill, 2006) and catalytic surface reaction (Gao and McCarthy, 2006). This review study elaborates a comprehensive assessment of the design, fabrication, and synthesis of interfacially active materials with strongmagnetic properties by various routes andmethods, also to discuss their unique properties and environmental applications. These unique materials are made of organic and inorganic nano scaled counterparts, where at a molecular level the interaction generates some interaction properties at the interface. In nanocomposites, inorganic nanostructures can be zero-dimensional, one-dimensional, two-dimensional or three-dimensional. Herein, we reviewed interfacially active and magnetically responsive nanocomposites materials, their physiochemical characteristics and environmental applications.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis of magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles
sections.text: Various synthesis procedures have been documented for the developmentofmagnetic nanoparticlewith diverse phases and compositions, such as Fe3O4 and g-Fe2O3 (Neveu et al., 2002), pure metals (Puntes et al., 2001), ferromagnetic particles like (MnFe2O4, MgFe2O4, and CoFe2O4) (Park et al., 2004), alloys i.e. FePt and CoPt3 (Shevchenko et al., 2002). Especially in the last decade, many research publications have been published describing the synthesis and shape-controlled, stability, and monodispersity of magnetic nanoparticles. Many very popular synthetic methods like co-precipitation, thermal decomposition, hydrothermal synthesis, micelle formation, and laser pyrolysis methods were reported and are in practice.We try to present the typical synthetic route and the corresponding formation mechanism.

sections.heading: 2.1. Co-precipitation
sections.text:
The formation of magnetic nanoparticles in proper size, shape, and surface morphology is a big challenge for researchers and scientists. Electron beam lithography and gas phase deposition are the wellknown physical approaches to synthesize magnetic nanoparticles, but

The wet chemical preparation routes of magnetic nanoparticles are more controllable, simple, and highly efficient with proper composition, control over the size, shape and surface morphology of the nanoparticles (Gupta andWells, 2004; Gupta and Curtis, 2004). Co-precipitation is a popular method for magnetic nanoparticles synthesis either Fe3O4 or g-Fe2O3 in which the aqueous salt solutions of Fe2+ and Fe3+ with the addition of a base is used. The shape, composition and size control of magnetic nanoparticlesmainly depends on Fe2+ and Fe3+ ratio, type of salts used, e.g. (sulfates, chlorides, perchlorates, nitrates, etc.), pH and the medium ionic strength (Sjøgren et al., 1994). Traditionally, a base was added to an aqueous mixture of Fe2+ and Fe3+ chloride (1:2 molar ratio) to prepare magnetite. The chemical reaction of Fe3O4 precipitation is given in Fig. 3 (Ali et al., 2014). Some considerable merits and demerits of the co-precipitation method are summarized in Table 1.
Thermodynamically in this reaction, the expected pH for complete precipitation of is between pH 9 and 14, also to control the molar ratio of Fe+3:Fe+2 as 2:1 in an oxygen-free non-oxidizing atmosphere. Magnetic nanoparticlesmay also be oxidized, whichwill influence the properties of the magnetic nanoparticles. To prevent the oxidation and possible agglomeration of magnetic nanoparticles, the prepared Fe3O4 nanoparticles are capped with inorganic or organic molecules during precipitation, and the fabrication of Fe3O4 must be carried out in an oxygen-free atmosphere using N2 gas. Passing nitrogen gas through the reaction mixture prevents not only the oxidation of magnetic nanoparticles but also decreases the particle size (Banfield et al., 2000).
Magnetite nanoparticles synthesized under different environments show differences in magnetic properties due to variations in structural disorder (Taylor et al., 2001), and antiphase boundaries creation (Zhou et al., 2001). The saturation magnetization (MS) values of nanoparticles are generally lesser than the corresponding bulk material, which are 30–50 emu/g for nanostructures and 90 emu/g for bulkmaterial. Many reports observed the reduction in magnetization value in magnetic nanoparticles. Coey performed the foremost study on the decrease in magnetization, which might be due to the noncollinear spins at the surface, of fine magnetic particles (Coey, 1971). Varanda et al. (2002) described that the presence of defects on particle surface could also affect themagnetic properties. As the surface curvature of themagnetic nanoparticle is larger for smaller particle size that may encourage disordered crystal orientation on the particle surface resulting in diminished saturation magnetization in nanoparticles. Unfortunately, magnetic nanoparticles prepared by co-precipitation method not showing monodispersity in particle size. It is worth noting that slow controlled growth and the short burst of nucleation is creating problems to produce monodisperse magnetic nanoparticles. These processes should be controlled to produce monodispersed magnetic nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.2. Thermal decomposition
sections.text:
Monodisperse magnetic nanoparticles with a small size can be produced by thermal decomposition of organometallics in organic solvents of the high boiling point also containing stabilizing surfactants. As a precursor, the organometallic compounds like metal cupferronates, metal acetylacetonates, [M(acac)n], or carbonyls, oleic acid, and hexadecylamine are usually employed as surfactants (Samia et al., 2005; Jana et al., 2004). For control and proper surface morphology of magnetic nanoparticles, the ratio of organometallics, solvent, surfactants, reaction time, temperature and aging period are the key parameters. If use zero-valent metal as a precursor, such as in carbonyls, initially the thermal decomposition results in the formation of a metal, however, further two-step processes can be used to generate oxide nanoparticles. To prepare monodispersed g-Fe2O3 nanoparticle, iron pentacarbonyl Fe(CO)5 can be heated in a mixture

The decomposition of cationic metal centers as precursors particles directly leads to oxides, Fe3O4, if Iron triacetate is decomposed in the presence of oleylamine, oleic acid, and 1,2-hexadecanediol (Sun et al., 2004). Nearly monodisperse magnetic nanoparticles 3 to 50 nm in size with proper surface morphology and controlled shape could be synthesized by heating iron oxide in carboxylic acid at about 300 °C at different reaction time (Fig. 4) (Jana et al., 2004).
Some considerable merits and demerits of thermal decomposition method are summarized in Table 2. Thermal decomposition technique can also be used to synthesize magnetic nanocrystals, such as MnO, Cr2O3, NiO, and Co3O4. The shape and size of nanocrystals can be controlled by the change in the reactivity (changing the concentration of fatty acid and chain length) and concentration of precursor particles. Primary amines and alcohols lead to faster the rate of reaction and lower the temperature. Park et al. (2004) preparedmonodispersedmagnetic nanoparticles using the thermal reduction procedure. They utilized sodium oleate and iron (III) chloride to generate a complex of iron oleate, which decomposed in different solvents such as trioctylamine, 1-eicosene, octyl ether and 1-hexadecene at temperatures between 240 and 320 °C. Generally, to control the particle sizes in the range of 5–22 nm depends on the aging period and reaction temperature. Aging play an important role in the synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles. Nanoparticles prepared by this process are dispersible inmany organic solvents including toluene and hexane but not assured that the particles are dispersible inwater too. The decomposition of iron oleate complex and iron pentacarbonyl at varying temperatures generate monodisperse iron particles of 6–15 nm that can further be oxidized tomagnetite (Park et al., 2005). The particles size and shape can be controlled under different reflux time at 4, 12, and 60 nm (Li et al., 2005). As the reflux time increases the spherical particle shape change to cubic like morphologies. Hu et al. (2006) introduced a newmethod of water soluble magnetic nanoparticles under the same reaction environments by adding poly(ethylene glycol) as a surface capping agent.

sections.heading: 2.3. Micro-emulsion
sections.text:
Amicroemulsion is a thermally andmechanically stable dispersion of immiscible liquids, in which the interfacial film of surfactant molecules stabilizes themicrodomain of one or both liquids. Inwater/oil emulsions, the aqueous phase is dispersed as tiny droplets, i.e., 1–50 nm in diameter and the surfactantsmake amonolayer aroundwater droplets in the continuous oily hydrocarbonphase (Paul andMoulik, 2001). Some considerable merits and demerits of the microemulsion method and its oriented products are summarized in Table 3. If the water/oil microemulsions contain the required reactants, the small microdroplets constantly collide with each other, merge, break repeatedly, and lead to the formation of a precipitate in the micelles (Gupta and Gupta, 2005). This precipitate can be extracted through centrifuge filtration by the addition of an organic solvent, such as ethanol or acetone. This idea of themicroemulsion
can be exploited like a nanoreactor to form magnetic nanoparticles. In past microemulsion technique was used to prepare cobalt/platinum alloys and metallic cobalt nanoparticles in reverse micelles of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (Carpenter et al., 1999). Same microemulsion and inverse micelles can be used to prepare spinel ferrites. MnFe2O4 magnetic nanoparticles with proper surface morphologies controllable sizes (4–15 nm) in water/toluene inverse micelles using sodium dodecyl benzenesulfonate as a surfactant (Liu et al., 2000). This process synthesis initiates with the aqueous solution of Fe(NO3)3, and Mn(NO3)2. Woo et al. (2003) used reverse micelles formed from oleic acid and benzyl ether in the presence of propylene oxide as a proton scavenger and FeCl3·6H2O as an iron source to fabricate iron oxide nanorods in sol-gel reaction. Variation in hydration state of gel, temperature, and pressure to control the phase of the nanorods under reflux in teralin. Magnetic nanoparticles can be prepared in many shapes like oblong cross-section, spheroids or as tube using the microemulsion technique (Tan et al., 2003). The microemulsion is a useful technique to prepare magnetic nanoparticles with controlled size and shape under different reaction condition. Also, the microemulsion is a working window for the fabrication, which is quite narrow, and the nanoparticles yield is low than co-precipitation and thermal decomposition synthetic methods. Microemulsion technique is not an efficient approach and challenging to scale up because it necessitates large quantities of organic solvents for the synthesis of desirable amounts of nanoparticles.

The system consists of solid metal linoleate, the liquid phase (ethanol-linoleic acid), and the water-ethanol solution under different temperatures and hydrothermal conditions. For example, CoFe2O4 and Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles can be developed in uniform sizes (9 and 12 nm). In another study, Deng et al. Monodisperse ferrite nanoparticles were obtained bymixing FeCl3, ethylene glycol, sodium acetate, and polyethylene glycol were mixed and stirred until the clear solution, then heated at maintained 200 °C for 8–72 h in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. Ethylene glycol typically acts as a reducing agent for the preparation of monodisperse metal nanoparticles, whereas sodium acetate prevents particle agglomeration as an electrostatic stabilizer and polyethylene glycol as a surfactant. However, to date, this mechanism is not completely understood, but themulticomponent reaction strategy appears to apply to the development of the desired product. Among all methods, the hydrothermal is a comparatively less explored although the synthesized nanoparticles are of high quality. The thermal decomposition gives nanoparticleswith control size and surface morphology and seems the best method until today. Microemulsions method is more applicable to the synthesis of monodispersed nanoparticles with many surface morphologies. However, microemulsion needs a large number of organic solvents, which is the main drawback of this method. More research has been done to prepare magnetic nanoparticles by co-precipitation and thermal decomposition and is in practice.
Repulsive electrostatic attractions stabilized magnetite nanoparticles prepared by co-precipitation method due to the positive charge on the particles (Bee et al., 1995), but nanoparticles synthesized by thermal decomposition are sterically stabilized in an organic solvent by surfactants or fatty acids (Sun et al., 2004).

sections.heading: 3. Interfacially active polymer magnetic nanocomposites
sections.text: First, we discuss a little about interfacial properties and the special wettability, synthetic techniques of materials with various kinds of surface properties, thenwewill review their environmental application including oil-water separation, removal of organic dye pollutants and inorganic heavy metals. Different types of metals or metal oxides can be used, i.e., Iron, cobalt, nickel, and oxide. However, to prepare perfect magnetic media, we usually preferred iron or iron-based compounds due to their high magnetic properties and low cost. Earlier studies indicate that a variety of iron-based compounds like ferrous oxide (Fe2O3), ferric chloride (FeCl3), ferrous sulfate (FeSO4), ferric oxide (Fe3O)4, ferric nitrate Fe(NO3)3 have been used (Hiemstra, 2018). The particle size can observe the performance of magnetic nanoparticles and found to be enhanced using the ultrafine size of 20 nm (Yaman and Öztürk, 2017).

sections.heading: 4. Interfacial surfaces with special wettability
sections.text: The interfacial properties and wettability represent the interaction between the liquid droplet and solid material. The contact angle of the liquid droplet on a solid surface used to quantify the interfacial property and surface wettability. A surface shows hydrophobic nature if the water contact angle is higher than 90° and lower than 90° indicates that the material is hydrophilic. However, the contact angle alone does not fully apprehend thewetting performance of a surface. Advancing contact angle is the contact angle of a liquid droplet with a solidliquid boundary, and the receding CA, θR, respectively (Lam et al., 2002). The most studied surfaces with interfacial properties are particularly repulsive towater (hydrophobic), to oil (oleophobic), or repellent to both oil and water (omniphobic) (Kota et al., 2012). There are some surfaces, which are hydrophilic in the air but oleophobic (wetted by water but not oil in air); such oleophobic surfaces are difficult to prepare because oil with low surface tension, usually wet a surface more than water, which has a high surface tension (Liu et al., 2013).

sections.heading: 5. Mechanisms and fabrication techniques
sections.text: The synthesis and fabrication techniques for interfacial materials with exceptional wettability properties mainly depend on their enablingmechanisms. These promising nanomaterials can be synthesized directly or may be modifying the substrate surface using an array of techniques and procedures (Guo et al., 2009). The formation surfaces with high water contact angle are comparatively easy, requiring materials with a very low surface free energy (Feng et al., 2002). Fabrication techniques of surfaces with special wettability and interfacial properties, such as those that are liquid repelling (omniphobic), hydrophilic but in-air and underwater oleo-phobic, with stimuli-responsive switchablewettability smart surfaces, have been described in previous reports.

sections.heading: 6. Environmental applications
sections.text: The explanation of the route and fabrication mechanisms of wettability and interfacial properties led us to the preparation of smart materials with special wetting properties. These smart nanomaterials have allowed several environmental-pertinent processes, including demulsification of oil/water separation, vapor condensation, membrane processes, biofouling mitigation, fog collection, and degradation of hazardous dyes and heavy metals. This section describes the recent and state of the art environmental relevant applications of magnetically responsive interfacial nanocomposite materials with up-to-date suitable examples.

sections.heading: 6.1. Oil/water separation
sections.text:
Wastewater contaminated with oils in the form of lubricants, fats, and petroleum products are considered a major environmental apprehension in recent days, due to potential toxicity to aquatic biota. Materials with special wettability and interfacial properties may show the major application in the demulsification of oil and water emulsion (Fig. 5). This is due to the different affinities of water and oil towards these smart materials (Xue et al., 2014). Removing water from oil is important for the effective recycling of separated water from various industrial sectors such as oil and gas, petrochemical, metal processing, food and pharmaceutical (Ali, 2012; Ali et al., 2014; Fakhru'l-Razi et al., 2009; Ali et al., 2015c). In the petroleum industry, demulsification plays a very imperative role in cleaning up the oil spillage, which has a major environmental concern (Ali et al., 2015a). It seems that currently implemented demulsification techniques to separate water from oil emulsions, mainly due to their high stability, have not been efficient enough to deal with this problem (Kingston, 2002), effectively. Chemical demulsification requires the addition of chemicals, which contaminate the separated water and cause serious environmental concerns. So, it is required to remove these chemicals. Besides, in highly viscus w/o emulsions it might be difficult to mix the chemical as demulsifier with the emulsion.
Although thermal demulsification has been useful in the demulsification procedures since the following heating up an emulsion, its oil phase viscosity will accordingly be reduced. Therefore, its fluidity will increase, and more droplet collision will take place. By increasing
the emulsion temperature, the solubility of surfactants in both oil and aqueous phases of an emulsion can be increased (Lemos et al., 2010). Also, at elevated temperatures, the difference in density of the phases, resulting in the heavier fluid (water) settles down and that the lighter fluid (oil) raises to build the top layer, is increased. Also, due to elevated temperatures within crudewax precipitation is reduced, which, accordingly, can help mitigate emulsion stability. Thermal demulsification is, however, energy intensive processes, heating a crude oil can promote loss of light components, which dictate crude oil price. Also, temperature increase while heating the crude oil can reduce the separation efficiency due to the formation of air bubbles, which can adsorb the surfactants found within the crude oil. If thermal treatment is integrated with chemical methods, in particular in case of heat sensitive demulsifiers, heat may deactivate the performance of that demulsifier. Besides, this method is considered ineffective to demulsify emulsions containing water contents (Rajaković and Skala, 2006). Likewise, the electrical resolution of emulsions with low water can be ineffective due to low conductivity.
Filtration method is effective but only in the case of gas purification. It has no proper applications in the case of heavy thick crude oil emulsions demulsification. Another problem with this method particularly in the offshore field, where space is usually restricted, is that it is usually coupledwith chemicalmethods to speed up the demulsification task for which additional hardware would be required. Also, all these methods need a long time (24 h) to complete one-step of demulsification to separate water from emulsions. sections.heading: 6.2. Removal of toxic dyes and effluents
sections.text:
A great surge has recently been noticed in the applications of synthetic dyes for numerous industries such as leather, textile, printing, dyeing, food, drugs, detergent, and cosmetics (Bilal et al., 2017; Chatha et al., 2017; Bilal et al., 2019b, 2019c; Liu et al., 2019). Approximately 10–15% of the dyes and associated intensely pigmented effluents from the above-mentioned industrial units are discharged in the water systems in several different ways (Chatha et al., 2017). Synthetic dyes accompanied by intermediates and degradation metabolites can generate highly toxic, carcinogenic, mutagenic or teratogenic aromatic compounds (Bilal and Asgher, 2015; Bilal et al., 2016, 2018b). Conventional physical or chemical control practices often seem insufficient for the complete exclusion of toxic dye pollutants. Concerted research imputes have recently been attempted to introduce a novel and highly competent strategies with a great capability to remove dye pollutants (Bilal et al., 2017; Rasheed et al., 2019a). Magnetic nanocomposites-based dye removal in this viewpoint occupies an exceptional position due to advantages of easier separation and recovery and proficiency to remediating a huge quantity of wastewater within the shortest period. In recent years, organic bio-adsorbent-assisted magnetic nanomaterials and biopolymers have beenwidely pursued to degrade and decontaminate toxic dye pollutants from wastewater (Reddy and Lee, 2013). For instance, Ferdosi et al. (2019) successfully fabricatedmagnetically recoverable nanocomposites (CoFe2O4/ZnO and CoFe2O4/ZnO/Ag) by adopting a simple precipitate method. The resultingmagnetic nanocompositeswere applied for degradation of acid brownand acid violet dyes under the treatment of UV light. Results showed that these nanomaterials presented great photocatalytic performance, resulting in 63% and 76% degradation of acid brown and acid violet dye, respectively. Likewise, a superior photocatalytic activity was detected for visible photo-catalyzed degradation and removal of crystal violet dye by newly developed multifunctional nanocomposites. Amid the different synthesized samples, the best photocatalytic performance was recorded in the case of 20% nanocomposite and primarily accredited to the effective separation and transport of photo-generated hydroxyl radicals and holes. Additionally, easy separation from the dyepolluted samples by means of a magnet renders these nanocomposites as versatile agents in large-scale remediation of various dye-containing wastewaters (He et al., 2019). Following a one-step and simple hydrothermal carbonization technique, Sayğılı (2019) synthesized highly functional innovative magnetic nanoconstructs and tested for adsorption of
methyl orange and methylene blue dye pollutants. The developed nanocomposites led to maximum adsorption of 8.9 and 11 mg/g for methyl orange and methylene blue, respectively. In another study, Nsabimana et al. (2019) fabricated high-performance Fe3O4/nitrogen dopedporous carbon nanoconstructs with potential adsorption, magnetic, and catalytic features, and utilized for the elimination of organic dye pollutants from water samples (Fig. 11) (Nsabimana et al., 2019). Remarkably more than 99.7% of rhodamine B and crystal violet dyes were removed, whereas the action of these nanomaterials completely eliminated thionine in a contact time of 15 min. Recycling and recovery profile revealed that the developed nanocomposites lost only 3.97%, 2.94%, and 3.36% of its original removal capacity for rhodamine B, crystal violet, and thionine, respectively, after five successive batch cycles. Simultaneous removal of two reactive dyes including reactive yellow 145 and reactive red 195 was reported from a textile dye effluent using cobalt ferrite-alginate biocompatible nanocomposite produced by a polymerization method. The nanomaterials retained absorptive capacity in wider pH environments ranging from 3.0 to 6.0. Notably, the occurrence of functional groups including hydroxyl, amine, ferrite, and carbonate on the surface of nanocomposite-based adsorbent presented a noteworthy role in eliminating these dyes from binary dye solution. Additionally, the magnetic separation and recyclability of the nanocomposites substantiate its suitability for efficient remediation of dye-containing water mixture (Jayalakshmi and Jeyanthi, 2019). Rezazadeh et al. (2019) investigated the adsorptive capacity of a magnetic nanomaterial hydrogel composed of poly(vinyl acetate-co-maleic anhydride)/melamine for Congo red dye pollutant. Results evidenced that the dye removal efficiency reached higher than 90%, under optimal adsorption conditions of reaction pH 5.0, 10 mg/L initial dye concentrations, and adsorbent amount of 10 mg. The proposed nanohydrogel data fitted well to Langmuir and adsorption isotherm models.

sections.heading: 6.3. Removal of heavy metals
sections.text:
Various industrial sectors including pigments, paints, glass and battery manufacturing, plating, and mining and extraction discharge a variety of different heavy metals into water resources (Kalia et al., 2014; Ali et al., 2019). The presence of these non-biodegradable pollutants in water bodies causes numerous diseases in aquatic and biotic creatures. Though themajority of these are not toxic, their occurrence beyondpermissible level leads to serious health complications. However, some heavy metals are lethal and carcinogenic exhibiting hazardous impacts on the whole ecosystem and living beings (Ali, 2012; Rasheed et al., 2018a, 2018b, 2019b). Therefore, it is highly meaningful to remove these lethal heavy metals from water bodies but appears a great
challenge for environmental engineers and scientists. A spectrum of classical and modern treatment approaches, such as adsorption, coagulation, irradiation, membrane filtration, reverse osmosis, chemical precipitation, ion exchange processes, electrochemical treatment, and biological means have previously been attempted to remediate metalharboring polluted wastewater (Bodalo-Santoyo et al., 2003; Wang et al., 2005b; Xing et al., 2007; Ersahin et al., 2012; Rasheed et al., 2017; Bilal et al., 2018c, 2018d). Owing to simplicity, high adsorption efficiency, cost-competitiveness, regeneration, and repeated usability for serval treatment batches, adsorption is considered one of themost reliable, promising, and technically viable methods for metals removal (Zamboulis et al., 2011). Reports have shown the pronounced adsorption ability of numerous kinds of materials, such as biopolymers, activated carbons, zeolites, chelating materials, and clay minerals from aqueous media. Inorganic magnetic nanocomposites exhibit poor adsorbing capacity, but the use of hybrid organic-inorganic polymers nanocomposites could substantially enhance their adsorption power. Furthermore, encouraging recyclability and real-time practical implementation revealed magnetic phosphate nanoconstructs as noteworthy candidates for the removal of Congo red and Pb2+ from water in successive batches (Zhang et al., 2019). sections.heading: 7. Challenges of up-scaling to pilot and commercial level
sections.text: Despite several benefits of different strategies to engineer novel interfacially active and magnetically recoverable composite materials which have been majorly employed for numerous applications including sustainable purification processes. However, many of these approaches are still being practiced at laboratory scale and needs highlevel up-scaling to pilot scale and commercial level. Several challenges such as (1) bulk or large volume processing on site, (2) standard operating procedurewith higher accuracy, efficacy, effectivity and reproducibility as currently different strategies have variable working conditions with certain merits and demerits (discussed above), (3) safety and environmental attributes for pilot and commercial level exploitation, remains to address to implement such purification processes in a most efficient and effective manner. The key technological advances suggest scaling-up potentialities of strategies exhibit free-surface methods or handling protocols and can support bulk or large volume processing on site. Process variability along with controllable accuracy and reproducibility are also among major concerns to address by engineering novel materials with industrially and commercially requisite features. In this context, more robust strategies will undoubtedly allow to improve existing or impart new functionalities in available technological alternatives and eventually up-scale forthcoming processes and products towards commercialization.

sections.heading: 8. Concluding remarks, general recommendations, and future perspectives
sections.text:
Inadequate availability of pure water and increasing global water scarcity necessitate the designing and development of novel and highly effective material for wastewater treatment. Interfacially active and magnetically responsive nanocomposites are currently fascinating
great attention for the treatment of contaminated water. Herein, we presented these magnetic nanoparticles, nanomaterials and their derived nanocomposites applied for the remediation of toxic pollutants like organic dyes and dye-containing wastewater, and heavy metals. Owing to exceptional properties including nano-size, large surface areas, structural robustness, high adsorption capability, magnetic features at wider pH ranges, and promising thermal and chemical stabilities, magnetic nanocomposites-based applications are progressively increasing in diversefields particularly to eliminate toxic environmental contaminants fromwater. Extensive literature survey and critical evaluation in this review revealed that these nanoconstructs exhibit an excellent adsorption performance in removing hazardous pollutants from water in contrast to many other identical adsorbents. Major concluding remarks of these magnetic nanoscale composite materials for sustainable wastewater remediation are as follows:
➢ Cost-efficiency, promising magnetic property, tunable features and feasibility are the major advantages of these nanocomposites as adsorbents. ➢ Stable and efficient adsorptive performance has been recorded even after recycling for several successive reaction cycles. ➢ Several factors including such as surface charge and the functional group, thermal steadiness and textural properties may influence the adsorption capacity of these materials. ➢ These nanocomposites possess higher adsorptive, removal and regeneration ability relative to the numerous other adsorbing materials. ➢ Potential salient features over awide-ranging pHs demonstrate their possibility for real-time practical exploitability. ➢ Pronounced efficiency of these adsorbents to wastewater contaminated with a range of toxic metal ions, organic dyes pollutants and hydrocarbons can switch towards a greener and sustainable society.
Despite substantial technological advancements, all studies carried out magnetic nanomaterials-based adsorption in batch processes with satisfactory outcomes, but none of the reports has scaled up to pilot or industrial columns that are an immediate concern to be considered. Moreover, complete water remediation by coupling nanoparticles with other new technologies required additional research for larger scale applications. In spite of the great progress on these issues, there is a dire need to introduce newer nanoscale materials with unique features including good capacity, selectivity, and ability to operate at industrial columns. Undoubtedly, the nanoparticles secure a bright future in water purification and remediation but necessitate the concerted efforts of researchers as well as industrialists to establish a rapid, reliable and economically feasible technology for water treatment. Taken together, it would be possible to address water contamination issues around the globe.
